prerequisites.fi: This course is intended for beginners. No previous knowledge in Finnish language is required.
prerequisites.sv: This course is intended for beginners. No previous knowledge in Finnish language is required.
prerequisites.en: This course is intended for beginners. No previous knowledge in Finnish language is required.

learningOutcomes.fi:
At course completion, you will:
- be able to introduce yourself and tell about your general background and current situation
- be able to manage in Finnish in common social situations
- be able to write short messages
- understand the main words used in your environment
- know more about Finnish customs

learningOutcomes.fi: After completing Microeconomic Theory II, the student should understand the connections between individual preferences and societal outcomes in the case of centralized mechanisms such as the Gale-Shapley algorithm in matching markets and the decentralized price mechanism in competitive markets. The student should also be able to construct and analyze different models of collective choice and market behavior and relate the stylized models covered in the course to more complex real life economic settings.

content.fi:
Part II of the Ph.D. and research master sequence in microeconomic theory is an introduction to collective decisions and market institutions. The emphasis in the course is on analytical concepts used in assessing societal decisions. Efficiency and stability are key ideas that recur during the course. Different economic institutions in diverse economic models are analyzed using these concepts and stability. The course builds directly on Microeconomic Theory I and it is essential that the students have a good understanding of decision theory and classical consumer theory. Some connections to strategic decision making covered in Microeconomic Theory III are mentioned, but the course does not assume any prior knowledge of game theory.
The central topics in the course include: Social Choice Theory, Assignment Models, Matching Models, and General Equilibrium Theory.

content.fi:

Moral hazard and imperfect monitoring.
Dynamic models of incomplete information including signaling and cheap talk.
Selected applications, for example: auctions, bargaining, market microstructure, reputation formation.

learningOutcomes.fi:
Opintojakson suoritettuaan opiskelija osaa:
  • tunnistaa keramiikka- ja lasialan kulttuurihistorian ja tämän päivän ilmiöiden yhteyksiä toisiinsa.
  • hankkia itsenäisesti syventävää tietoa keramiikka- ja lasitaiteen alalta.
learningOutcomes.sv:
Opintojakson suoritettuaan opiskelija osaa:
  • tunnistaa keramiikka- ja lasialan kulttuurihistorian ja tämän päivän ilmiöiden yhteyksiä toisiinsa.
  • hankkia itsenäisesti syventävää tietoa keramiikka- ja lasitaiteen alalta.
learningOutcomes.en: After completing the course the student is able to comprehend how the culture history of glass and ceramic design connects with contemporary phenomenon, and is able to explore glass and ceramic design's history independently.

content.fi: Opintojaksolla tutustutaan keramiikan ja lasin kotimaiseen ja ulkomaiseen kulttuurihistoriaan ja ajankohtaisiin ilmiöihin luentojen, alan kirjallisuuden ja museovierailujen kautta. Opiskelijat toteuttavat pienimuotoisen tutkimuksen valitsemastaan aiheesta, joka voi olla esimerkiksi tietty alalla vaikuttanut historiallinen tyylisuunta, tekniikka, taiteilija tai alan yritys. Tutkielma esitellään muulle ryhmälle suullisesti kuvaa ja tekstiä yhdistelevän esitelmän muodossa.
content.sv: Opintojaksolla tutustutaan keramiikan ja lasin kotimaiseen ja ulkomaiseen kulttuurihistoriaan ja ajankohtaisiin ilmiöihin luentojen, alan kirjallisuuden ja museovierailujen kautta. Opiskelijat toteuttavat pienimuotoisen tutkimuksen valitsemastaan aiheesta, joka voi olla esimerkiksi tietty alalla vaikuttanut historiallinen tyylisuunta, tekniikka, taiteilija tai alan yritys. Tutkielma esitellään muulle ryhmälle suullisesti kuvaa ja tekstiä yhdistelevän esitelmän muodossa.
content.en: In the course the students are introduced to the both Finnish and international culture history of ceramics and glass, and contemporary phenomena. Learning is supported with lectures, literature and excursions to museums. In the course the students excecute a short research on topic of their own choice, including certain style, method, artist or a company. The research is presented in class.

content.fi: The course aims to provide methods and development tools to design and implement advanced torque controllers for multiphase motors configured as parallel three-phase winding sets. These multiphase topologies, typically nicknamed “multi-three-phase”, are experiencing an increasing development in transport electrification, especially in recent years. Beyond this choice, several reasons are well described in the literature and briefly summarized hereafter.· The modularity of multi-three-phase (M3PH) drives allows the adoption of three-phase power electronics technologies, reducing costs and development time.· An M3PH machine can be configured as multiple three-phase winding sets operating parallel and whose level of magnetic coupling among them can be designed properly according to the performance indexes of power density and short-circuit fault tolerance.· M3PH drives implement the three-phase fault tolerance. In the case of a fault involving one three-phase unit (winding set plus inverter), this is turned off easily using several methods available in the literature (circuit breakers, PWM stop, or active short-circuit). The following advantages are thus obtained.o Each of the remaining three-phase units operates as a balanced load, avoiding low-order harmonic content on the corresponding inverter’s dc-link.o Each of the remaining three-phase sets produces a smooth torque without introducing a low-order harmonic ripple. According to the above scenario, the course will present the step-by-step procedures to develop and implement high-performance torque control algorithms for M3PH permanent magnet synchronous motor (PMSMs) drives, considering the cutting-edge machine typologies typically used in traction applications like PM-assisted synchronous reluctance (PM-SyR). The course topic features several multidisciplinary aspects, including but not limited to i) dynamic modelling of M3PH PMSMs, ii) performance identification of M3PH PMSMs, and iii) design and implementation of modular torque controllers for M3PH PMSMs.The course is highly applicative, and most of the concepts presented find direct application in the industry. This course will assume M3PH PMSMs for high-power density applications as study cases. Therefore, benchmark torque controllers for these motors will be developed and implemented.

learningOutcomes.fi:
Kurssilla perehdytään sosiaali- ja terveyspalvelujen tuotantojärjestelmään sekä vaikuttavuusperustaiseen johtamiseen sosiaali- ja terveydenhuollossa. Kurssin suoritettuaan opiskelija:
- osaa arvioida sosiaali- ja terveyspalvelujen tuotantojärjestelmää osana nykyistä terveys- ja hyvinvointiekosysteemiä sekä uudessa sosiaali- ja terveysjärjestelmän integraatiossa.
- osaa tunnistaa menetelmiä kustannusvaikuttavuuden arvioimiseen.
learningOutcomes.sv: Kursen ger insikt i social- och hälsovårdens produktionssystem, särskilt värdebaserade styrsystem. Efter kompletterande av kurs kan studenten:- Bedöma social- och hälsovårdens produktionssystem som en del av nuvarande och framtida hälso- och välfärdssystem.- Kan grunderna för utvärdering av kostnader och hälsonytta.
learningOutcomes.en: The course serves as an introductory course to social and health care production system, especially to value-based healthcare management. After completing the course, the student can:- evaluate the production system of social and health care as a part of the current and future health and welfare system.- identify methods for evaluation of cost-effectiveness.

content.fi: Systeemiajattelun perusteet sosiaali- ja terveydenhuollossa. Toimialan erityispiirteet. Tuotantotaloudellisten menetelmien soveltaminen sosiaali-ja terveydenhuollossa. Digitalisaatio, muutosjohtaminen, kustannusvaikuttavuuden arvioiminen.
content.sv: Grunderna för systemtänkande inom social- och hälsovården. Sjukvårdens särdrag som tjänsteproduktion. Applicering av produktionsekonomiska metoder. Digitalisering, förändringsarbete, kostnadskalkylering.
content.en: The basics of systems science in social and health care. Special characteristics of health care service production. Application of industrial engineering and management methods. Digitalization, Change leading, Cost-effectiveness evaluation.

assesmentMethods.fi: Seminaarit, luennot ja luentokohtaiset tehtävät (ennakkotehtävät/luentoraportit, artikkeleita 1-2 per luento) sekä tapaustutkimus (case-tehtävä), joka laaditaan ryhmissä. Ryhmät esittelevät harjoitustyötä seminaareissa.
assesmentMethods.sv: Seminarier, föreläsningar och föreläsning med förhandsuppgifter och föreläsningsrapporter, läsning 1-2- artiklar per föreläsning, och fallstudie (case-uppgift) som grupparbete. Grupperna presenterar sina övningsarbeten under seminariet.
assesmentMethods.en: Seminars, lectures, lecture pre-assignments and reports, reading of 1-2 papers per lecture, and case study group assignment. The groups present their case assignments in the seminars.

substitutes.fi: Korvaa kurssin TU-E2140 Sosiaali- ja terveydenhuollon tuotantotalous.
substitutes.sv: Ersätter kursen TU-E2140 Social- och hälsovårdens produktionsekonomi
substitutes.en: Substitutes course TU-E2140 Healthcare Operations Management.

learningOutcomes.fi:
Kurssin suoritettuasi:

- osaat esitellä itsesi sekä kertoa pääasiat taustasi ja nykytilanteestasi
- pystyt selviytymään suomeksi tavallisimmissa, rutiininomaisissa tilanteissa
- osaat laatia lyhyitä kirjallisia viestejä
- ymmärrät tärkeimpiä ympäristössäsi esiintyviä sanoja
- tunnet suomalaista tapakulttuuria.
learningOutcomes.sv: Efter slutförd kurs: - kan du presentera dig själv och berätta huvudsakerna om din bakgrund och din aktuella situation - klarar du dig på finska i de vanligaste, rutinartade situationerna - kan du skriva korta skriftliga meddelanden - förstår du de viktigaste orden som förekommer i din omgivning - känner du till finska seder och bruk
learningOutcomes.en:
At course completion, you will:
- be able to introduce yourself and tell about your general background and current situation - be able to manage in Finnish in common social situations - be able to write short messages - understand the main words used in your environment - know more about Finnish customs

content.fi:
Arkielämän perussanastoa ja kielen perusrakenteita (partitiivi ja genetiivi, verbityypit 1-5, omistusrakenne)

learningOutcomes.fi:
Kurssin suoritettuasi:

- osaat esitellä itsesi sekä kertoa pääasiat taustasi ja nykytilanteestasi
- pystyt selviytymään suomeksi tavallisimmissa, rutiininomaisissa tilanteissa
- osaat laatia lyhyitä kirjallisia viestejä
- ymmärrät tärkeimpiä ympäristössäsi esiintyviä sanoja
- tunnet suomalaista tapakulttuuria.
learningOutcomes.sv: Efter slutförd kurs: - kan du presentera dig själv och berätta huvudsakerna om din bakgrund och din aktuella situation - klarar du dig på finska i de vanligaste, rutinartade situationerna - kan du skriva korta skriftliga meddelanden - förstår du de viktigaste orden som förekommer i din omgivning - känner du till finska seder och bruk
learningOutcomes.en:
At course completion, you will:
- be able to introduce yourself and tell about your general background and current situation - be able to manage in Finnish in common social situations - be able to write short messages - understand the main words used in your environment - know more about Finnish customs

prerequisites.fi: Compulsory prerequisites: PHYS-E0460 “Introduction to Reactor Physics”
prerequisites.sv: Compulsory prerequisites: PHYS-E0460 “Introduction to Reactor Physics”
prerequisites.en: Compulsory prerequisites: PHYS-E0460 “Introduction to Reactor Physics”

learningOutcomes.fi: After finishing this course, the student has hands-on experience on the behaviour of a nuclear reactor. The student knows how reactor power is measured, what the role of delayed neutrons is in reactor control, how the reactivity of a nuclear reactor is controlled in practice, how control rods are calibrated, and how a reactor is brought to a critical state. Additionally, oral and written presentation skills are practiced.
learningOutcomes.sv: After finishing this course, the student has hands-on experience on the behaviour of a nuclear reactor. The student knows how reactor power is measured, what the role of delayed neutrons is in reactor control, how the reactivity of a nuclear reactor is controlled in practice, how control rods are calibrated, and how a reactor is brought to a critical state. Additionally, oral and written presentation skills are practiced.
learningOutcomes.en: After finishing this course, the student has hands-on experience on the behaviour of a nuclear reactor. The student knows how reactor power is measured, what the role of delayed neutrons is in reactor control, how the reactivity of a nuclear reactor is controlled in practice, how control rods are calibrated, and how a reactor is brought to a critical state. Additionally, oral and written presentation skills are practiced.

content.fi:
The essential content of this course is provided by five days of nuclear reactor exercises at VR-1 research reactor of Czech Technical University CTU. The visit to VR-1 is scheduled together with CTU and is in Period IV. Due to practical limitations, the course is organized for 6-12 participants per year.
In preparation for the reactor exercises, an introductory lecture is organized in early period III. Exercise instructions are studied in Period III and each participant presents one of the exercises in a half-day seminar that is organized before the VR-1 visit.
CTU staff instructs and supervises reactor exercises at VR-1. Measurement results are analyzed during the course of the exercises in small groups. Additionally, each student writes a more comprehensive laboratory report on one of the exercises by the end of Period IV or early Period V.

learningOutcomes.fi:
After completing their personal CHEMARTS project, the student
1) has in depth knowledge on selected biobased materials and technologies; 2) is able to plan, execute, document and present their experimental working processes and results in a professional way; 3) understands how to develop innovative ideas through interdisciplinary collaboration, experimenting with materials and hands-on prototyping.

content.fi:
Students work individually, in pairs or in small groups with an aim of developing a material or product idea of renewable, bio-based sources. The project plan including a schedule needs to be presented for and agreed by the tutoring faculty before the student(s) can start their project. The process and results will be presented in a joint seminar when the working period ends.
Note: Every student working at the CHEMARTS lab needs to pass laboratory safety course before entering the laboratory.

asuntorakentamishankkeissa.
learningOutcomes.sv:
Kurssi antaa valmiudet ymmärtää miten poliittiset päätökset ja 
toimenpiteet ohjaavat urbaanien asuinympäristöjen suunnittelua ja 
toteutusta. Tavoitteena on, että kurssin suoritettuaan opiskelijalla on 
kokonaisvaltainen näkemys asuntorakentamisen yhteiskunnallisesta 
merkityksestä ja arkkitehdin erilaisista rooleista erilaisissa 
asuntorakentamishankkeissa.

content.fi:
Kurssi keskittyy asumiseen ja sen taustalla vaikuttaviin asuntopoliittisiin prosesseihin. Aihetta lähestytään arkkitehtuurin ja arkkitehdin ammatin näkökulmasta.Luentojen mahdollisia aiheita ovat mm.
  • asuminen valtakunnan politiikassa ja kuntapolitiikassa
  • asumisen hinta ja siihen vaikuttavat tekijät
  • erilaiset asumismuodot
  • uudet rakennuttamisen tavat ja yhteisöasuminen
  • rakennuttajien ja arkkitehtien yhteistyö
Kurssin sisältöä kehitetään vuosittain. Ajantasainen tieto löytyy MyCoursesta.

learningOutcomes.fi: After completing this course, you will be able to - implementing various service, strategic, and systemic design tools in real service case projects (such as software as a service - SaaS, circular, AI-driven services, regenerative, sustainable e-commerce services, and software services) - being comfortable working across various time zones within the EU and collaborating with service design and other professionals from diverse cultural backgrounds and perspectives - developing and delivering online service design workshops utilising digital service design templates and tools for different audiences and stakeholders - selecting and utilising appropriate service design tools depending on the service design project and service industry - applying service design learnings from the practical assignments directly to the company work and various daily work scenarios where innovative service design solutions are required - expanding your service design portfolio with a new project case by showcasing results from a company case analysis and an online circular workshop - further explore literature, relevant videos, and podcast materials related to service design tools, planet/environment/life-centred design, sustainable customer experiences, and AI-driven services. The service design course was updated to reflect the latest developments in service design, which are affected by the dynamic and constantly changing geopolitical situation, technological advances in AI and other disruptive technologies, and the ever-changing environment. The sustainability theme was selected due to limited resources, climate change, and the urgency of reducing consumption. The course is an excellent opportunity to experience contemporary AI-formed service design and circular business services firsthand while analysing and redesigning carefully selected sustainable and/or technology-driven services weekly in a group of diverse professionals across the EU.

content.fi:
The service design course was upgraded and updated to reflect the latest
 developments in service design, which are affected by dynamic and 
constantly changing geopolitical situations, technological advances in 
AI and other disruptive technologies, and the ever-changing 
environment. The sustainability theme was selected due to limited 
resources, climate change, and the urgency of reducing consumption. 
Therefore, the course is an excellent opportunity to experience 
contemporary AI-formed service design and circular business services 
firsthand. A red thread in this service design course is analysing and 
redesigning carefully selected sustainable and/or technology-driven 
services weekly in a group of diverse professionals across the EU.The course starts by discussing what service design is in the current, 
ever-changing context and its possible future developments. The second 
session presents numerous service design tools that are process or 
customer-focused, life-, planet or environment-focused, systemic, or 
strategic. The third session expands on systemic and strategic service 
design dimensions following the lecture that examines the changing 
landscape of value creation in the complex service ecosystem level. The 
lecture placed before the digital co-design workshop looks into 
sustainable customer experiences and their personalisation with adopting
 AI. The co-design workshop is the highlight of the course that enables 
the redesign of company cases by utilising sustainable strategies on 
product/service, business, and ecosystem level. In the last reflective 
session, participants present the course learnings implemented in their 
company’s day-to-day work activities. The lectures are complementary to 
each other.

The sustainability theme was selected due to limited resources, climate change, and the urgency of reducing consumption. Therefore, the course is an excellent opportunity to experience contemporary AI-formed service design and circular business services firsthand. A red thread in this service design course is analysing and redesigning carefully selected sustainable and/or technology-driven services weekly in a group of diverse professionals across the EU.The course starts by discussing what service design is in the current, ever-changing context and its possible future developments. The second session presents numerous service design tools that are process or customer-focused, life-, planet or environment-focused, systemic, or strategic. The third session expands on systemic and strategic service design dimensions following the lecture that examines the changing landscape of value creation in the complex service ecosystem level. The lecture placed before the digital co-design workshop looks into sustainable customer experiences and their personalisation with adopting AI. The co-design workshop is the highlight of the course that enables the redesign of company cases by utilising sustainable strategies on product/service, business, and ecosystem level. In the last reflective session, participants present the course learnings implemented in their company’s day-to-day work activities. The lectures are complementary to each other.

The second session presents numerous service design tools that are process or customer-focused, life-, planet or environment-focused, systemic, or strategic. learningOutcomes.fi:
After completing the course the student
  1. Is familiar with the mathematical structure and postulates of quantum mechanics
  2. Can differentiate between the terms quantum-mechanical state and wavefunction
  3. Can build a quantum-mechanical Hamiltonian from the classical description of a physical system
  4. Can solve the eigenstates and eigenvalues of the Schrödinger equation in simple situations and knows how to generalize the computation to situations where analytical solution is challenging. 
  5. Can integrate the quantum evolution and the expectation values of physical quantities for simple systems.
  6. Can apply creation and annihilation operators to solve the eigenstates of a one-dimensional harmonic oscillator.
  7. Can apply the quantum formalism to model a qubit and a register of several qubits. 
  8. Can predict measurent probabilities from a given quantum state.
  9. Can apply perturbation theory to compute eigensolutions in a situation where analytical solutions is challenging.

content.fi: Hilbert space and Dirac notation; Bases and operators; Properties of (Hermitian) operators; Eigenvalues and eigenfunctions; Postulates of quantum mechanics including quantum measurement; Expectation values and variance; Uncertainty relations; Continuous-variable bases: coordinate representation, momentum basis; Quantization recipe for physical systems; Schrödinger equation and unitary temporal evolution; Qubit (two-level system); Bipartite system and entanglement; Quantum gates and algorithms; Commutator and conserved quantities; Solving 1D harmonic oscillator using creation and annihilation operators; Excited states of a 1D harmonic oscillator; Free particles and plane waves; Particle in different 1D potentials: box, square well, constant potential with periodic boundary conditions; Scattering and tunneling through barriers; Time-independent perturbation theory; Temporal dependence of operators; Different pictures of quntum mechanics; Rabi oscillations

learningOutcomes.fi: This course will provide the students with a solid understanding of the foundations of organizing, organizational forms, and organizational phenomena in business. After participating in the course, students will (1) be able to distinguish between various forms for organizing business at the organizational and inter-organizational level; (2) know when a certain form is suitable; and (3) understand how organizing can be impacted by technological and institutional changes. Students undertaking this course will become familiar with a series of real-world, contemporary organizational phenomena and learn different theoretical perspectives that can elucidate these phenomena. This course bridges theory and practice, exposing students to a variety of conceptual tools and methods to evaluate novel situations.

content.fi: Organizing is shaped by a multitude of institutional and technological conditions which are constantly changing. In this course, we aim to shed light on the evolving phenomenon of organizing in a market-based society by drawing on various theoretical perspectives. We will examine organizing both as a practical challenge facing business leaders and as a phenomenon of societal importance.

learningOutcomes.fi:
The course covers recent quantitative urban
models that rationalize the observed spatial distribution of economic activity
within cities. We will focus on two strands of methodological advances: (1)
"equilibrium sorting" models that use properties of market equilibria
to characterize preferences over locational amenities, and (2)
"quantitative spatial equilibrium" models that can be used to
undertake counterfactuals for general equilibrium impacts of
empirically-realistic policy interventions. This entails: i) working with
spatial data to generate the necessary model inputs; ii) setting, estimating,
and inverting the primitives of the model; iii) using numerical procedures to
solve for the spatial equilibrium and conduct counterfactual analysis.
learningOutcomes.sv:
The course covers recent quantitative urban
models that rationalize the observed spatial distribution of economic activity
within cities. We will focus on two strands of methodological advances: (1)
"equilibrium sorting" models that use properties of market equilibria
to characterize preferences over locational amenities, and (2)
"quantitative spatial equilibrium" models that can be used to
undertake counterfactuals for general equilibrium impacts of
empirically-realistic policy interventions. This entails: i) working with
spatial data to generate the necessary model inputs; ii) setting, estimating,
and inverting the primitives of the model; iii) using numerical procedures to
solve for the spatial equilibrium and conduct counterfactual analysis.

learningOutcomes.fi:
1. Develop an ability to effectively present research ideas and progress
  2. Gain proficiency in critically analyzing one's own and others' research
  3. Learn to constructively integrate feedback
  4. Enhance networking skills by engaging with peers and faculty, fostering potential collaborations and gaining insights into diverse research perspectives within the field of entrepreneurship
  5. Improve professional presentation and communication skills, essential for academic conferences, seminars, and future career opportunities in academia and industry.
  6. Broaden understanding of current trends, methodologies, and theoretical approaches in entrepreneurship research, contributing to personal academic growth and the broader research community.

content.fi: This seminar presents an opportunity for PhD students/candidates in entrepreneurship to share their evolving research foci and outputs, and to receive valuable feedback on it. Focusing on innovative methodologies and emerging trends in entrepreneurship, participants will showcase their work, emphasizing preliminary findings and theoretical frameworks. This collaborative platform encourages open discussion, critical analysis, and constructive feedback from peers and faculty experts. The aim is to refine research approaches, address potential challenges, and enhance overall academic rigor. This session serves as a pivotal step in advancing research quality and contributing to the dynamic field of entrepreneurship studies.
